title: kids dont return class receive less online school double staff
story: CHILDREN who dontto class next month could receive less online teaching as schools will need double the staff in for classes that are social distancing, parents have been warned.The government currently plans for pupils in reception, year one, and year six toon June  and hopes to see other primary school year groups back by the end of June.The majority of pupils in secondary school are not expected tountil the beginning of the next academic year in September.But there are now warnings that any year groups that do notmay not have the same level of remote teaching available to them from next month, thereported.Official advice from the Department of Education says that class sizes in reopened schools should have a -pupil limit - half the usual size - to allow for social distancing.That is expected to mean more staff than normal will be needed to supervise regular classes, and that fewer will be available for remote teaching.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the National Association of Headteachers, told thethat “splitting classes in order to reduce the risk of transmission requires twice the number of staff, leaving fewer teachers to support those other children still at home.”Kevin Courtney, joint general secretary of the National Education Union, added that teachers “cannot be in more than one classroom at once”.Schools across the UK closed indefinitely in March amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic, and normal classes replaced by online sessions and other forms of home learning.The gradual decline of new cases in the country has sparked a fierce debate about when schools should reopen with fears about the possible impact of the move.Kids across the country face falling behind without proper lessons and continued homeschooling from parents who are also trying to juggle their own jobs and working from home.Professor Alan Smithers, Director of Centre for Education and Employment Research at University of Buckingham, has accused unions of setting a spurious list of unreasonable and vague demands and warned that the future of the countrys children was hanging by a thread.And yesterday saw at least one union advise its members to prepare to reopen on June  after receiving assurances from government scientic advisers.But public health experts have expressed concern that opening schools too early could lead to a resurgence of cases, while teaching unions have said it could endanger the health of staff.A number of unions have called on the government only to reopen schools once safety measures like comprehensive testing of children and staff can be guaranteed.The last week has seen unions in talks with ministers and calling on the government only to reopen schools once precautions like testing for children and staff can be put in place.Yesterday, we told how parent Jemma Thompson would refuse to send her son back as she didnt want him to be treated as a guinea pig.

title: holidays this year safe
story: Visit Britain boss Patricia Yates says the crisis could actually boost British tourism and urged the nation to take a holiday later in the year.Appearing in front of the DCMS committee, Ms Yates claimed staying in the UK was vital for the industry.She said: “To get British tourism up and running this summer, and this summer is hugely important is we need that domestic audience.“The worrying thing is the lack of confidence in the British public about travelling, so  per cent who have a holiday booked for July and September don’t think that holiday will take place.Only  per cent of people are thinking of booking a domestic holiday for the summer.And that’s much lower than competitor destinations, in Italy  per cent of their domestic holiday will holiday domestic.Ms Yates was also asked about Greeces offer today to not quarantine Brits for two weeksthey were allowed to come here without being detained.Greek tourism minister Harry Theoharis called for the UK to stop the two-week quarantine for Greek tourists, and would reciprocate the favour for Brits entering Greece in turn.She said: Its quite interesting, it would be good to choose the countries available to us for inbound markets.We have an international market, our regional director is saying America is ready to go.An airbridge between us and America could be very valuable to us.Ms Yates urged Brits to travel within the UK, and pleaded with the Government to do more to convince them.She said: It has to be the year of domestic tourism.There’s a real job to be done there in convincing people it’s socially responsible to travel and enjoy a holiday and that it’s safe to do so.”The tourism expert also claimed UK travel could be boosted beyond the next  months by the crisis.Brits are currently allowed to take day trips but cannot stay overnight.Hotels and hostels will be allowed to open as part of the Governments three phase plan, but this wont be til July at the earliest.Yesterday trips to France were looking more unlikely than ever this summer as it was revealed the -day quarantine exemptions wont include tourists.Spanish holidays are also unlikely - the country has since banned Brits until June  at the earliest, with UK tourists also forced to quarantine for  days.With the quarantine also enforced when ing to the UK, it could mean four weeks of annual leave for a two week holiday.Last month European Commission president Ursula von der Leyen said she was optimistic people would be able to travel as coronavirus was brought under control.She also revealed Visit Britain had held discussions with the Government about an extra bank holiday in October.Ms Yates explained: I think that’s an idea that’s being considered, to have a bank holiday around the October half term.Because what we’re going to need to do is not just stimulate people in July and August but really extend the season this year for the domestic market.Yesterday Brits were given hope for summer holidays after Grant Shapps confirmed ministers are looking at travel bridges between countries with low Covid infections.The Transport Secretary said that the Government were looking at allowing people to fly between countries where the spread of the virus is low.Speaking in the House of Commons, Mr Shapps said it the plan of only allowing travel between Covid-safe areas was just one thing being looked at, alongside the plan to quarantine all arrivals for  day.Everyone who comes into the UK will have to isolate for a fortnight under Government plans, which are set to begin in June.Mr Shapps said today in the House of Commons: The final details of the quarantine scheme will be released soon, coming in early next month.And he added: It is the case that we would indeed consider further improvements for example, things like air bridges, enabling people from other areas and countries who have themselves achieved lower levels of growth virus infection, to come into the country.So those are the active discussions, but will go beyond what will initially be a blanket situation.As it stands, only lorry drivers and key workers are expected to be exempt from the new quarantine rules, then they come in - dashing hopes of a summer holiday for many.But the idea of travel bridges to areas of low infection will give Brits a boost thatour rate of infections continues to fall, Brits may be able tto jet off on a getaway in the coming months.

title: coronavirus timebomb india cyclone amphan
story: A MASSIVE cyclone is set to batter the coast of India, forcing tens of thousands of people to break the coronavirus lockdown to seek shelter.The country’s weather office said Super Cyclone Amphan had reached winds of up to  mph over the Bay of Bengal on Monday night and was expected to make landfall tomorrow.Such wind speeds could make Amphan one of the biggest storms to hit India in about a decade, said officials.India imposed the world’s biggest lockdown in March to contain the coronavirus which has infected more than , people and killed ,.The states of Odisha and West Bengal were moving families to more than , shelters in government offices.Schools and colleges were hastily converting coronavirus quarantine centres into cyclone shelters.But the need to maintain social distancing has left the authorities with a headache.“We have just about six hours left to evacuate people from their homes and we also have to maintain social distancing norms,” said S.G. Rai federal disaster management official told Reuters.He added that that the cyclone “could wash away thousands of huts” as well as crops.Trains plying thousands of migrant workers from the Indian capital New Delhi to eastern states, after the coronavirus lockdown of the country’s rail system was eased.Mrutyunjay Mohapatra, India’s meteorological chief said warned of uprooted trees, electric poles and damage to old or temporary housing.India, with a coastline , miles experiences more than a tenth of all the world’s tropical cyclones, the bulk of them on its eastern coast.In neighbouring Bangladesh, officials intensied preparations as the cyclone could trigger the worst storm in about  years along the country’s low-lying coast.The country’s Meteorological Department said the cyclone could flood vast areas with tidal waves  to  feet higher than normal, along with heavy rainfall and high wind speeds.Junior Minister for Disaster Management and Relief Enamur Rahman has ordered the preparation of thousands of cyclone shelters and makesht structures to take more than  million.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dont wear masks asthma coronavirus
story: PEOPLE who have asthma or other lung conditions should not wear a face maskit makes it more dficult to breathe, experts have warned.The Government issued advice last week telling Brits to wear face masks where they cant stay two metres away from other people to stop the spread of COVID-.Masks can help stop the spread of coronavirus - by catching droplets which infect other people - they may not stop the wearer from getting the virus, but prevents them passing it into the others.Asthma UK said: For some people with asthma, wearing a face covering might not be easy. It could make it feel harder to breathe.The government has advised the people with respiratory conditions dont need to wear face coverings - soyou are finding it hard, then dont wear one.The Government guidance says: If you can, wear a face covering in an enclosed space where social distancing isn’t possible and where you will come into contact with people you do not normally meet.This is most relevant for short periods indoors in crowded areas, for example, on public transport or in some shops.It adds: Face coverings should not be used by children under the age of  or those who may find it dficult to manage them correctly. For example, primary age children unassisted, or those with respiratory conditions.For people who suffer from asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder , cystic fibrosis, chronic bronchitis, emphysema or lung cancer, wearing masks can be particularly dficult.Immunology and infectious diseases specialist at New York University Dr Purvi Parikh told the MailOnline: Those with lung conditions are in a catch- because they probably need the mask more than the average person but it can be challenging to breathe.A tight mask on your face can make anyone have trouble breathing.I even get it when Im treating my patients.She said warm weather could make it even more dficult.Were approaching summer-time so its hot outside, and when youre consistently breathing hot air on top of your own breath that can be quite uncomfortable.The Government has published a how-to guide to help people make their own facial coverings - and stresses people should not be buying medical grade masks needed by NHS staff and social care workers.Dr Parikh said people who can wear masks comfortably - eventhey have asthma or COPD - should do so where possible.She said: [Vulnerable] people should absolutely wear masksthey can.Not only will it protect them but people with asthma or COPD may actually sp of the virus because theyre coughing, sneezing and breathing harder than other people. px,px, px" You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Labour leader Keir Starmer has picked a close ally who worked for the Labour Party under Tony Blair to be his new General Secretary, the Mirror understands.David Evans, who was assistant general secretary of the Labour Party between  and , is the favourite to take over the top job.Current general secretary Jenny Formby, a key ally of Jeremy Corbyn, resigned as boss of the partyaposs headquarters earlier this month, creating a vacancy.The new General Secretary is expected to be elected by the partyaposs ruling National Executive Committee next Tuesday. Mr Evans, whose previous jobs for the party included regional secretary in the North West, left front-line Labour politics in . But he remained a powerful figure behind the scenes and had close working relationship with Labour councils across London. He set up a research and communications company, The Campaign Company, which works with local authorities, health and third sector bodies. Mr Starmeraposs chief-of-staff, Morgan McSweeney, who worked for TCC as director of communities between  and  is believed to have recommended him. Senior sources said the Labour leader wanted him on the shortlist for the top job ahead of next weekaposs vote.  The Mirror understands that neither Anneliese Midgeley, political director of Unite, nor Lisa Johnson, director of external relations for the GMB, applied for the job. The deadline for applications was midnight last night. The longlist process begins today, with shortlisting interviews, carried out by NEC officers, taking place this Thursday, and final interviews next Tuesday.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSchools are ramping up plans for reopening, despite ongoing fears they could help the spread of Covid-. Class sizes will be halved and even kids’ artwork banned from the walls. Parents have been given a glimpse of how schools will operate when they reopen to more pupils as lockdown restrictions are eased. Class sizes will be halved, start times will be staggered and contact will be severely reduced for children in reception, Year  and Year  whoto primary school from June . Plans for the reopening were ramped up as the Government announced tests would be available to everyone over five who shows symptoms. It comes as the Department of Health revealed , people had died in the UK after testing positive for coronavirus, a rise of  on the previous day. The Health Secretary Matt Hancock insisted the UK proposals for schools tois “sensible”. He said: “It is very clear that the number of children who are badly affected by this disease is very, very, very small. “So, the proposals that we’ve made for schools are safe and they are sensible.” He added it is up to head teachers whether staff are allowed to wear face masks or visors while they teach. Paul Whiteman, the general secretary of school leaders’ union NAHT, has urged the Government to write to him setting out the scientic evidence behind the decision. It is understood the Government has examined an Australian study which showed kids are “not the primary drivers of Covid- spread” in schools. The Government is looking at a phased reopening of primary schools from June . A planning guide – from the National Education Union, Unite, Unison and GMB – advises schools that two-metre social distancing must be maintained as there is a lack of scientic evidence that children do not transmit the virus. Political leaders in Liverpool and Hartlepool have pledged to keep schools closed while the infection rate remains higher in their regions. And Bury council in Greater Manchester said that while high levels of the infection remain in the North West “the borough will not be reopening schools on June ”.  Greater Manchester mayor Andy Burnham said: “I worry the June  date is too soon for the North. “The virus is at a dferent stage in dferent parts of the country. It can’t be fair parents and pupils here are being told it’s OK for schools to reopen when their areas still face a higher risk than the South.” Cabinet minister Oliver Dowden repeatedly refused to rule out teachers, heads or council leaders being “penalised” for defying advice to open from June . Marsden Infant and Nursery School near Huddersfield, West Yorks, has laid out markings on the floor to keep children separate.  Head teacher Frances Swallow and colleague Sarah Yates were also pictured converting the assembly and dining hall into a classroom. At Kempsey Primary School in Worcestershire, children of key workers were photographed yesterday keeping apart while eating, studying and washing their hands. Elsewhere inidual head teachers are refusing to act, while some are warning of huge problems. Evelyn Davies, of Coldfall Primary School in north London, said: “You can’t get young kids to keep away from each other and to not touch each other, it is impossible.” Denmark became the first European country to reopen its primary schools on April . Other countries with schools back open include Belgium, Austria and Portugal.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA third council in England is set to defy government advice to reopen schools next month, saying that the risk to pupils and staff is unacceptable. Bury in Greater Manchester has now joined Hartlepool and Liverpool as they reject plans to allow teachers and childrento the classroom on June . The council has now written to all headteachers in the area outlining the reasons behind their decision. The statement claimed the reopening classrooms would “pose an unacceptable risk to pupils, staff and communities of vulnerable people.” Labour councillor for Bury Tamoor Tariq said on Twitter that the governmentaposs position is ill advised and not one we can follow. Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson warned last week that he would resist sending kids back at the beginning of next month, saying he had concerns about whether schools would be able to operate safely. He told BBC Newsnight: “I’m not going to take risks with children’s lives or with staff and teaching professionalsapos lives.” While leaders in Hartlepool said it they would be taking a measured and cautious approach to this. Last weekend, senior minister Michael Gove told parents it was safe to send their kids back to school - but confusingly added aposthere would be risksapos. He told the BBC’s Andrew Marr: “It is absolutely safe,” then said the only way to be sure was to “stay at home” as there is “always, always... a risk”. Teaching unions fear it is unsafe for pupils and staff to go back to school on June . And Labour wants the test and trace system to be put in place before schools .  Mr Gove told BBC’s The Andrew Marr Show: Yes, teachers will be safe in schools... Some of the best leaders in current education have said that it is absolutely safe for children to , absolutely safe for teachers and other staff toas well. But askedhe could guarantee no teacher would be infected as a result of ing to the classroom, he said: The only way ever to ensure that you never catch coronavirus is to stay at home completely. There is always, in any loosening of these restrictions, a risk of people catching coronavirus. You can never eliminate risk, but... it’s extremely unlikely any school is likely to be the source of a Covid outbreak, andfor any reason there are risks we can take steps to mitigate them. Universities aposcould rush to reopen campusesapos Universities could rush to reopen campuses when it is still unsafe to do so amid increased competition to attract students, MPs have been told. Jo Grady, general secretary of the University and College Union , warned that leaving the decision to institutions could be dangerous as financial pressures could encourage them to reopen prematurely. The Office for Students , the higher education regulator, has urged universities not to make any promises to students that everything will be back to normal in the autumn termthis is not the case.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has refused to condemn Donald Trump for using an unproven drug that his own government has warned could be dangerous. The President prompted shock last night when he revealed he has been taking the malaria drug hydroxychloroquine for a week and a half. He claimed: Iaposve had a lot of good stories, anditaposs not good, Iaposm not going to get hurt by it. Yet the US Food and Drug Administration is warning not to take the drug to treat coronavirus outside of hospitals or clinical trials. The FDA said it can cause a dangerously rapid heart rate, especially when combined with certain other drugs, and has not been shown to be safe and effective for treating or preventing COVID-. Trump was slammed today by the UKaposs former chief scientic advisor Sir David King, who declared every word he says should be ignored. Sir David told ITV: This is not the pronouncements of a person who is listening to the scientists. He is making it up as he goes along. Yet the UK government refused to condemn Trump. Cabient minister Therese Coffey told BBC Breakfast: I think it surprised a lot of people last night when President Trump announced this. However, that really is a matter between him and his clinician rather than the government of the UK.  “What we are seeing is good ongoing work about situations regarding things like the vaccine development.” Askedthe comments were irresponsible, she said: “I really think it’s a matter between him and his clinician which I do not want to comment on. It is not the first time the UK has refused to criticise the notoriously prickly US President. Last month Downing Street refused to condemn the President for suggesting people could inject disinfectant into their lungs.Trump previously said as Dr Deborah Birx, the head of White House coronavirus response, looked on aghast: “I see the disinfectant where it knocks it out in a minute. One minute. And is there a way we can do something like that, by injection inside or almost a cleaning  “Because you see, it gets on the lungs, and it does a tremendous number on the lungs. So it’d be interesting to check that. So that you’re going to have to use medical doctors, but it sounds - it sounds interesting to me.” The President later claimed he was being sarcastic but there were reports of some US citizens drinking disinfectant after his comments. Englandaposs Deputy Chief Medical Officer Jenny Harries said at the time: Nobody should be injecting anything. We should be using evidence-based and properly trialled treatments that we know will be safe. But ministers and No refused to join the criticism. Boris Johnsonaposs official spokesman said: We can only speak to the UK response and in terms of disinfectant, I’m certainly not aware that it’s anything that’s being recommended. story: NewsCoronavirus track-and-trace app delayed for weeks in blow for lockdown exit hopeHealth Secretary Matt Hancock previously said the NHS track-and-trace app would be ready by mid-May, however it will now be delayed for weeks in a blow to the Governments lockdown exit strategyShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe roll-out of the Governments track-and-trace app will be delayed for weeks " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe nationwide roll-out of the track-and-trace coronavirus phone app will be delayed for weeks in a fresh blow to the Government’s lockdown exit strategy. It came as ministers said tests will now be available to anyone aged five and over with symptoms. Loss of taste and smell were today added to the list of symptoms that should warn sufferers to self-isolate to prevent passing on the disease – months after other countries had included it. Health Secretary Matt Hancock told MPs: “Everyone aged five and over with symptoms is now eligible for a test. That applies right across the UK from now.” The testing expansion is meant to reassure parents and teachers as schools prepare to reopen next month.But today Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab was unable to confirm the infection-tracking app would be ready for rollout before then.Mr Hancock said last week the NHS app would be ready by “mid-May” – but today No said it would be ready “in the coming weeks”. However, less than a quarter of IT experts believe it will be effective, a survey for the Chartered Institute of Information Technology found. It came as deaths rose by  to , – the lowest daily increase since lockdown began. Health chiefs face questions over the failure to include loss of smell – or anosmia – as an official symptom until now. There were warnings it meant up to , cases had been missed with sufferers unknowingly infecting friends and family. Prof Tim Spector of King’s College London slammed Public Health England and the Government for sticking to only temperature and new persistent cough as “red flag” symptoms.He estimated , to , coronavirus cases have been missed as a result since the outbreak began.He said: “There’s no point telling people to be alertthey don’t know the symptoms.”  Prof Jonathan Van-Tam, England’s deputy Chief Medical Officer, said some data suggested over half of Covid- patients may suffer from loss of smell. At least  countries had already included it on their list of symptoms. Ministers also restated their goal of hitting , tests a day by the end of the month. Fewer than , cases have been confirmed in the UK, but many more may have been missed due to a lack of mass testing.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKnown as the British Oskar Schindler, Sir Nicholas Winton single-handedly saved  children, most of them Jewish, from the Holocaust. But he stayed quiet for  years, with the world only finding out about his heroism in  when his we found a dusty old scrapbook in their attic. It contained names, records and pictures of the hundreds of Czechoslovakian children that, had it not been for Nicholas, would have been sent to Nazi concentration camps with their parents.Today, on what would have been his th birthday, Sir Nicholas Winton has been honoured with a Google Doodle.This is the story of his extraordinary act of bravery. In December , British stockbroker Nicholas Winton set up a rescue mission for Czechoslovakian children, working out of a Prague hotel room. He met with desperate parents who knew that to save their childrenaposs lives, they would have to give them up and smuggle them to another country to be raised by strangers. They would never see them again. Nicholasapos work was incredibly dangerous. It involved bribery, secret networks, forgery, nine dferent railroad trains and a ton of paperwork. And it was also incredibly expensive. Donors in Britain sent money, with Nicholas also paying out of his own pocket to get the children to safety.  He paid endless bribes to Gestapo agents, and covered the expenses of children whose parents had already been killed or forced into hiding. In early , a few months after the operation began, Nicholas flew back to the UK and began looking for new homes for the children. With the help of his mother, he printed ads in newspapers and posted bulletins at synagogues around the country, asking for foster families to come forward. He appealed to the Home Office for visas that would allow the children to enter the country - and when they didnapost come through in time, he forged them. In March , he began to evacuate the children. Nicholas initially arranged for  to say goodbye to their parents and get on a train in Prague. They travelled through the Third Reich, through Nuremberg and Cologne, before eventually arriving in Holland and catching a boat across to Great Britain - and to safety. After the success of this first evacuation, Nicholas arranged for eight more trains to cover the same route.  Tragically, only seven of the trains made it. While the final train was making its way through Germany, Hitler invaded Poland and all borders were closed. The children never made it to Holland, and the train was never seen again. Nicholas had saved  children, bringing them to Great Britain before the Second World War started. Nicholas kept quiet about what he had done, not even telling his we or children about his heroic actions. But in  his we, Grete, found a scrapbook in their attic with documentation detailing what her husband had done. She gave it to a Holocaust historian, who in turn contacted the BBC. They invited Nicholas onto the programme Thataposs Le, where they showed the scrapbook and explained what Winton had achieved.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIdentical twins of five months sparked a medical mystery after one suffered a rare coronavirus-related illness while the other remained in perfect health. Mum Hannah Godwin, , noticed Leia had a rash and high temperature while sister Thea was “healthy and happy”. Leia was rushed to Royal Gwent Hospital in Newport, South Wales, from their home in nearby Risca three weeks ago. She was treated for an inflammatory disease in young children linked with an extreme reaction to Covid-. Hannah said: “It got dficult for her to breathe and she got transferred to critical care. “She went through a scary time. God knows what could have happenedshe hadn’t had the treatment early on.”  Leia’s arteries also began to swell to a le-threatening size. Hannah said: “The consultant said, ‘If there’s a rupture she’s not going to survive’.” Leia was then transferred to Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospital for Wales in Cardf, where she tested positive for antibodies to Covid- and was treated in isolation. Hannah and husband Simon, , hope she will be allowed home soon. Doctors plan to do genetic testing to understand why she reacted the way she did. They also want to take blood from Thea to seeshe has had Covid- – andso, why she did not react the same way.The news comes as the link between the illness and coronavirus remains unclear, with some children testing positive for COVID-, and others negative.A report by doctors in Birmingham last week indicated that there was a link between the two illnesses, but now the chief scientist of the World Health Organisationhas revealed that this may not be the case. Speaking on the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show, Dr Soumya Swaminathan said: “Very recently there have been some reports of children getting admitted with a strange syndrome, something that looks like sepsis, something that looks like a disease called Kawasaki disease, which causes inflammation in the blood vessels.“Now, itaposs not very clear what the links are between Covid- and this syndrome. There are some children who tested positive for the virus and some who havenapost. “The WHO has discussed this with a group of international paediatricians about how to approach this, and the need to collect more data. We put out a note two days ago, which requests doctors to provide information in a standardised format so that we can quickly learn as much as possible about the syndrome.

He still cycles to restaurants and takeaways, picks up the food then rides to the customeraposs house to drop it off. But the reason behind many of his orders is now dramatically dferent, and heaposs no longer just delivering a lazy dinner but providing an essential service to the most vulnerable people in our community. Since lockdown was brought in, the delivery company has started working with convenience shops to take groceries to people who are self-isolating or shielding.  Robin, , has been a driver with the delivery company for four years, but admits he did consider quitting when the lockdown was introduced. He told : There were a couple of days when I felt like I really didnapost want to go out, but then as time passed I realised that I should. I was more concerned at the start, it was just a complete shock. It was a shock for everybody. People are so grateful for us to bringing their stuff to them. Itaposs a great feeling, it feels like youaposre contributing to keeping people safe. People used to order for a treat but now theyaposre ordering because they really need stuff and they donapost want to leave their house.  One moment that sticks in his mind is when a customer left him a thank you note and a chocolate bar to thank him for dropping groceries off to her. The note said: Hereaposs a wee treat to get you through the rest of your sht. Robin, who has been a Deliveroo driver for four years and lives with his girlfriend, who is also a key worker, said: Iaposve never been tipped in chocolate before. It was so nice and I really wasnapost expecting it. Itaposs good knowing youaposre helping people.  Robin does everything he can to protect himself and customers while out delivering, like all his Deliveroo colleagues. He uses hand sanitiser before entering and once heaposs left each restaurant, and does the same as he arrives at the customeraposs house. While there have been a lot more orders, the quieter roads have made the actual delivering part of the job much easier. Robin said: Weaposre not seeing as much of the customers, itaposs down from about  per cent to about  per cent. Weaposre leaving the food on the doorstep. But thereaposs still a little bit of contact from a distance. His fellow driver Alex Smith, , delivers in Horsham alongside his university studies.  He knew he wanted to carry on working as soon as he saw how grateful people were, and heaposs made a mini documentary about his time out delivering. He said: I was determined to carry on. I did it for a little bit, and then I saw how important it was to vulnerable people. Being able to help someone is really nice. There are vulnerable people who canapost get food, and being able to deliver to them is important. People are saying thank you for working, it just made me think that someone has got to do it and I want to be the one to do it.  What I like most is how grateful people are. People are really nice when youaposre dropping off. Like Robin, Alex is making sure heaposs doing everything he can to keep customers safe and following all the procedures, but admits he tries not to think about the personal risk. He said: Maybe I am more at risk but I donapost mind, people need to eat.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs many as .million people are currently shielding from the virus. The rest of the country may be celebrating the gradual lting of lockdown but those deemed high risk are likely to remain in isolation much longer. But many of our most vulnerable people are finding remarkable ways of coping.A Channel  documentary, Old, Alone and Stuck at Home, tracks the lives of some who show incredible bravery as they tackle the lockdown. Here, a few of them tell how they’re managing in such dficult situations... Desmond Gittens, Grandad Desmond Gittens, , is being looked after during lockdown by daughter Aisha, , in her house in Notting Hill, West London, with granddaughter Malika. He moved there from his flat in Cricklewood, North West London, where some of his close friends in the Afro-Caribbean community contracted the virus and died. He is devastated that he cannot say goodbye to them properly. Desmond : I’m a diabetic, I’ve come out of prostate cancer and I’m being treated for other issues like high blood pressure.My independence is really important to me. I didn’t think the lockdown would last this long – I thought it would be two weeks at the most. But we’re getting on OK. I have a drone and there’s a garden where I can fly it. And we have a treadmill where I do  or  minutes’ morning exercise. I usually do a big morning walk in my neighbourhood, so I’m missing that. In all the time I’ve been here I’ve been out once. I miss my friends. A couple passed away but I couldn’t go to their funerals. And I’m missing the rest of the family. Initially I was being shielded for my age, not my ethnicity. But when you see the statistics about BAME people I realise it’s for both. I’m  and I know full well I’m not here forever. But I’m trying to make sure this virus doesn’t take me. Aisha : When I knew lockdown was imminent I talked to family members and we made the decision it would be betterhe stayed here.I don’t knowhe’d have managed on his own. I’d have been constantly worried. For Dad it’s hard. It’s not just about eating, it’s about getting on a bus, going to get things for a meal. A conversation with the people in the shop. It’s those simple things. But he can’t go out. What’s alarming is the lack of information. We don’t know why dferent sections of the community are more at risk.  These figures are shining a light on the racism and inequalities that exist in this country. Disparities in health, housing, education and employment. Yyvonne and Chris Milne, The couple from Malvern, Worcs, have spent lockdown looking after daughter Clare, , who was one of the first children diagnosed with brain condition Rett Syndrome in . They are anxious about transmission of Covid- and her ability to withstand it. Yvonne founded charity Rett UK and was made an MBE in . Yvonne : We started a week before official isolation because of the limits of the care home to public access. Also, we’re in the vulnerable group, being over . And we’re important to Clare for the future. We’ve battled to keep her alive. Rett Syndrome affects one in , females.It results in profound physical and communication dficulties. They have no speech. And she has abnormal breathing. Clare is in that group who are the most vulnerable. I’m frightened about Clare catching coronavirus. It seems like the focus is only just coming on to social care settings. There has been a lot said about the NHS and that’s quite right. But there are people in care homes who are just being disregarded – in le and in death.Hopefully, ministers will look more closely at what needs to be done. Our daughter is being cared for by people who love her, highly trained people. But they are not paid a good rate for the fantastic job they are doing. Before the virus struck, Clare would come home to us every other weekend and stay two nights. We used to visit. We can’t visit now. But she does come home with us once a week.  We use full PPE. All the time, we are taking temperatures. We feelshe loses contact with us, she will lose her interest in le At the beginning of this we didn’t think she could survive lockdown, physically and mentally.Clare had pneumonia and sepsis last November and was in hospital  days. They didn’t think she would survive. Her lungs were compromised. That makes us worry more about her getting any infection.We want to make sure whatever le she has left is as good quality and as easy as it can be. She likes to do things she has always done. She has a routine. When she’s here it’s similar to being in the home – there are set feeding times. But we can do other things with her here she enjoys. We have a fish pond and she likes that. We sing to her. There are special times. Susie Davies, With serious underlying conditions, Susie, of West London, has had oian and breast cancer and recently received large doses of chemotherapy. She is vulnerable to infection but has found many ways to keep busy.  Susie : I’ve found things perfectly OK. I seem to have a lot to do. I’d already limited my activities because I’m on chemo and my immune systems have fallen so I’m rather susceptible to bugs.I don’t go to any of the cultural things I used to do, like go to galleries, cinema or theatre. I was visiting friends as well but now I’m completely limited. But I do make sure I speak to people every day. I have a nice Zoom group where we set each other tasks every weeks. I want to counter this stereotype of older people and people being shielded in their houses. It is not depression and helplessness and people screaming out of a window. I’m reading and watching boxsets. I’m also sorting out my house. You have to look ahead – although I have no intention of dying. I want to organise my possessions so they have a home. I want mine to go to inidual people so I have been labelling everything. I don’t ever have a dull moment. I miss not being able to go out driving. That’s something I’d love to do but it’s justyou break down or something then you are really in trouble. The only place I really have to go is the hospital. I don’t think my cancer can ever be cured but I’m very lucky. I feel very well. The prognosis is ultimately not good but who knows  It’s not like I’m young and my le is being stolen from me. But I do see it as a kind of cosmic joke that I can’t go out when time is so important. I don’t see this as a battle. I see this as all I can do to help my body. We have real lessons to learn from this lockdown. This is a great opportunity to improve society and right so many wrongs.

title: matt forde severe asthma means
story: NewsopinionMatt Forde: Severe asthma means Ive not stepped outside for  weeksMatt Forde, comedian and podcaster, revealed that he hasnt stepped outside of his home in  weeks, due to his severe asthma which has left him on inhalers for most of his leShareCommentsByMatt Forde:,  MAY NewsopinionMatt Forde has revealed he has been told to shield himself against coronavirus " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIt’s almost ten weeks since I set foot outside. It hadn’t occurred to me how weird that was until I mentioned it on Twitter and I was immediately inundated with messages from friends and well-wishers. It was lovely, who doesn’t like a reminder that some people don’t wish them dead  But it also made me feel a bit guilty. Loads of people were checking in on me but I’m absolutely fine. I don’t feel worthy of concern because I know that all I’ve had to endure is a minor inconvenience compared to the severe experience so many people will be going through. I’d only tweeted about it jokingly anyway, because I was gagging for a Big Mac from McDonald’s. Still am, by the way. I found out I had to shield on the same day that I found out I had severe asthma. One logically led to the other, but it was news to me. Despite having had a string of chest infections over the last few years which have required strong medication, I didn’t realise I had severe asthma. I realise that sounds monumentally dense. Just so you don’t think I’m a complete moron, I knew I had asthma. I’ve been on inhalers all my le. I didn’t think I was taking them for a laugh. My asthma has rarely stopped me doing anything. In  I ran the London Marathon and until I had those chest infections, it hadn’t stopped me exercising. I’d had asthma attacks as a kid but I was always charging around playing football outside and I would like to use this  to apologise to all those households in Nottingham whose windows and cars were hit by my stray balls. . I presumed severe asthma meant you couldn’t walk a few steps without carting an oxygen tank around. Well, it turns out that due to two items of medication I’m on, I’m classed as having severe asthma. So that means I have to shield. One thing I need to make absolutely clear is this: I know I’m lucky.  I don’t have noisy or aggressive neighbours, I don’t have children to home school, I don’t have mental health issuesand I don’t have a disability - althoughsevere asthma gets me a blue badge, I’m up for it. The radio show and podcasts I hosts can be done from home so I’ve got plenty of work to be getting on with, I live with my girlfriend and I can chat to friends over Zoom. Oh and I’ve got a tonne of booze in. I should’ve mentioned that one first. All the conditions that could make it easier are present, apart from some outdoor space. When you add that all up, staying indoors in those circumstances is definitely a bit weird, but it’s not hell. The hardest part has been there being no football on the telly. If football was on, this could have been the best  weeks of my le. The next best thing after football, as we all know, is politics. No, really, please, don’t walk away. We are living though such a signicant period. Just as every personal experience of this crisis will be recounted for generations to come, every political decision taken will be scrutinised and debated well into the future.  Whatever your assessment of the government’s handling of the crisis so far, one thing that can give us all reassurance is the presence of Keir Starmer. Cynics like to believe that politics shouldn’t be about iniduals, but they tend to support parties led by awful ones. Iniduals can make a huge dference – look at what Starmer has done already. He’s calmly, maturely held the government to account. On top of that, even more impressively, he’s almost made Labour look normal again.That achievement cannot be underestimated. It would be like passing Frankenstein’s monster off as a real person without anyone noticing the stitches and bolts.There are still over two weeks to go until the earliest point that I’ll be allowed out. Which makes me sound like I’m doing time.

story: NewsMeghan Markle and Harry celebrate wedding anniversary after dramatic two yearsMeghan Markle and Prince Harry tied the knot two years ago at St Georges Chapel, Windsor Castle. In the time since, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex have welcomed Archie Mountbatten-Windsor to the world and split from the Royal FamilyShareCommentsByLaura ElstonMilo Boyd:,  MAY NewsPrince Harry and Meghan, Duchess of Sussex wave on their wedding day " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailToday the Duke and Duchess of Sussex are celebrating their second wedding anniversary. Prince Harry and Meghan Markle said their vows in St Georgeaposs Chapel, Windsor Castle, on May , .In the two years since they tied the knot in front of the royal family, celebrity guests and a worldwide television audience of millions much has changed. The Queenaposs grandson Harry and former Suits star Meghan welcomed son Archie Mountbatten-Windsor last year. The latest addition to the Royal Family turned one on May . The couple also sparked the Megxit crisis and quit as working royals just one year,  months and  days after their high-profile wedding. Harry and Meghan opened up about their struggles dealing with royal le and the intense media interest, in a television documentary about their Africa tour in the autumn of . The Duke also addressed a long-reported rt between himself and his brother the Duke of Cambridge, saying they were on dferent paths and have good and bad days in their relationship. After a six-week break in Canada, Harry and Meghan issued a bombshell statement in January this year without warning the Queen and the Prince of Wales, saying they wanted to step down as senior royals to be financially independent, while still supporting the monarch.  The Queen held an emergency summit at Sandringham with Harry, the Prince of Wales and William. It was announced a few days later there would be no dual role for the Sussexes, meaning they would have to walk away from the monarchy completely. From March , , Harry and Meghan stopped using their HRH styles and ceased to be senior working royals, in favour of a le of personal and financial freedom. The couple, now living in Los Angeles where they have been in lockdown amid the coronavirus outbreak, are preparing to launch their new charitable organisation Archewell - named after their son.It will replace their now-defunct Sussex Royal brand. Plans to launch the venture have been delayed while the world battles the coronavirus. Former actress Meghan became the first mixed race person in modern history to marry a senior British royal when she walked down the aisle two years ago.  The Sussexesapos ceremony was a romantic, star-studded affair, with the duchess dressed in an elegant, minimalist boat-necked pure white wedding gown by Clare Waight Keller at Givenchy. Her five metre-long veil featured flowers from all Commonwealth countries and was held in place by Queen Maryaposs diamond bandeau tiara, loaned by the Queen. An emotional Harry was captivated by his bride as they met at the altar, telling her: You look amazing. Crowds flocked to see the newlyweds - the new Duke and Duchess of Sussex - who kissed on the West Steps of the chapel.  Guests in the gothic church included George and Amal Clooney, Oprah Winfrey, Idris Elba, Serena Williams, Carey Mulligan, James Blunt and James Corden, and a number of Meghanaposs Suits former co-stars. Dubbed a royal wedding like no other, the nuptials combined British traditions with ersity and modernity. Sounds of a gospel choir filled the venue, with US preacher Bishop Michael Curry delivering a y, impassioned, rousing address on the power of love. Prince George and Princess Charlotte were among the pageboys and bridesmaids, and the Duke of Edinburgh, recovered from a hip operation, put in an appearance.  There was drama in the run-up to the big day, with Meghanaposs father Thomas Markle pulling out of walking her through the Quire to the altar due to illness, and after being caught staging paparazzi photographs. But the Prince of Wales stepped in to perform the symbolic role. Thousands lined the streets of Windsor to watch Harry and Meghan as they went on a carriage procession in the Ascot Landau through the town and the Long Walk in Windsor Great Park.

story: Andy Walker’s latest contribution to BwB states how amazing a simple question can cause ‘animosity’.He takes up the story: “I was recently at a junior match, standing among an array of veteran boys club former players of assorted ability.“This included the likes of Davie Bruce, Danny McAlpine and John Daley.“They all played at one time for Butterburn Youth Club.“I put the question to them: ‘Who was the first Butterburn player to play for Celtic FC ’“I produced a picture of Butterburn and told them he was in the photo.“After many mute moments, and a lot of shaking of heads, their squirming got the better of me.“A further clue was he played at least two games in Europe for the Celts, and maybe more, possibly five.“The half-time whistle at the junior game saved their bacon.“During the second half, I was approached by other unknown former Burn players asking for the name, and I said ‘You are standing beside him!’“It was Hamish McAlpine.”Andy further explained: “The situation arose, at the start of season of - when Celtic had a goalkeeping problem.“Packie Bonner, Allen McKnight and young prospect Andy Murdoch had long-term injuries, and the team were touring Austria and Czechoslovakia.“While there, they played two trialists – an U  keeper and an Austrian keeper.“However, both were considered not to be up to scratch.“An SOS was sent out and former Tannadice hero Hamish McAlpine responded.“He had just left United, so, really, it was a no-brainer.“I spoke to Hamish recently and he reckons it was five appearances.“Ultimately, it did not lead to anything long-term as Celtic signed Alan Rough and Ian Andrews.” vw, px"  This photo is from  and was a football match between local solicitors and the Dundee Constabulary. title: craig conway film jon daly dundee united scottish cup
story: Craig Conway has revealed he warmed up for Scottish Cup glory with Dundee United by watching “The Commitments” with Jon Daly.Conway’s two goals in the th and th minute, following David Goodwillie’s opener, secured the Cup for United in  and sealed the winger’s place in Tangerines folklore.Around , Terrors fans travelled through to Glasgow for the showpiece occasion, many wracked with nerves.But Conway was totally relaxed before producing his man-of-the-match performance.“The night before the Final I was sharing a room in the team hotel with big Jon Daly,” said the -year-old, currently with Salford City.“We just tried to have a quiet time and then watched the film The Commitments.“I didn’t really have trouble sleeping. To be fair, I am usually like that before a big game.“I had already gone through everything in my mind about what I wanted to do on the pitch and how to prepare.”Conway, who has also played for Cardf City and Blackburn Rovers, added: “There was little in the final itself as we went in at half-time with the scores level.“But I was always sure thatwe kept doing what we had been doing the first goal would come.“Thankfully it did and then I was able to get my two goals as well.“It is something you are always asked: ‘Is it the sort of thing you dream about when you are a kid,’ and genuinely it is.“When you are playing in the park with your mates, you hope that one day you can score in the Scottish Cup Final so to do it was one of the highlights of my career and one of the best feelings you can get.“Once the final whistle goes, it is all a bit of a blur but it was just great to see the sheer delight on everyone’s faces.“It is so hard to put into words exactly how you felt but there was a massive sense of achievement.”After the trophy was handed to United, the celebrations really took off on the way back to Dundee before the players partied the night away alongside ecstatic fans, with Conway heading for his favourite city night spot.“It was just carnage on the bus with all sorts of nonsense back to the club and then it was into the town to celebrate,” said the seven-times-capped ex-Scotland star.“I’d had a lot of nights out in Fatties but everyone was just having a great time and it was the best atmosphere ever there.“Everybody was absolutely buzzing and it was great to be able to celebrate with the fans.“Everyone was together like a big family.“After a couple of hours’ sleep, we then had the parade on the open-top bus.‘To be honest, a lot of us were still drunk! In fact the celebrations continued for most of that week.“We had expected the fans to turn out but we were absolutely stunned by the thousands in the city square and at Tannadice. It is something that will stay with me forever.“The  years have just flown by but there will always be a special bond with the lads.“It was one of the best days of my career and my medal still has pride of place in a room in my house.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: dundee fc john nelms spfl
story: The result of Tuesday’s failed SPFL inquiry vote has vindicated Dundee managing director John Nelms, according to a Dark Blues fan chief.Following weeks of back-biting and sniping over the Dens Park supremo’s now infamous voting U-turn at the start of April, two thirds of league clubs voted against an independent inquiry.With nine out of  Championship clubs voting ‘no’, chairman of the Dundee Supporters# Association, Kenny Ross, believes a “clear statement” has been made in relation to Nelms# actions.And Ross also insists the response from Dundee fans at large has been one of acceptance.He told the Tele: “The club seem quite relaxed about what’s been going on the past couple of weeks, not saying anything.“John Nelms doesn’t say much at the best of times but I think that relaxed attitude is echoed by the fans.“With nine out of  Championship clubs voting no, there is also a clear statement there and I think it vindicates John Nelms.“Personally, I would have liked an inquiry because there are questions that need answered but it was pretty overwhelming from Dundee’s fellow Championship clubs and % of all the clubs that it wasn’t wanted.“It’s clear from that there isn’t really a problem from most clubs on the U-turn – the majority wanted it with over % voting that way and the Deloitte inquiry said there was no wrongdoing.“With reconstruction talks ending, fans do wonder what John Nelms achieved through the U-turn but I think we are all past it now. I’ve not had anyone on to me about it all, there’s very little online about this week’s vote – I don’t think anyone really cares now.”Rangers vehemently led the call for a vote on an independent inquiry into the SPFL’s conduct during the coronavirus shutdown, as well as Dundee’s actions in changing their vote.That led to Gers fans bombarding online posts from the club and DSA social media, but Ross believes the reaction from fellow Dundee supporters is telling.He added: “Anytime the DSA are posting stuff on social media, we have to go through and delete loads of stuff.“It’s almost amusing now – Dundee fans responding generally laugh at them. Dundee have been getting hammered but they are not rising to it all and that, I think, shows the general feeling of the support.“It is bizarre because Dundee’s vote hasn’t affected Rangers really – our club has been affected more because there’s now no play-offs.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: family trio leaving bags of fun for children in lockdown in arbroath
story: An Arbroath man has stepped up to give kids a few moments of fun during what has at times become a very challenging lockdown.Nicky Oliver, a father-of-two from Arbroath, has been putting together small toy packs for kids in his local neighbourhood in an effort to bring a bit of joy to their days.The packs, which include a colouring-in sheet, a little toy and a small sweet, are hung from a line on Nicky’s driveway on Culloden Crescent.There they can be picked up by local children out on their daily walk.Nicky said: “It’s been really good. I just want to see kids happy and smiling at this time.“I can see the drive from my kitchen window so sometimes I’ll just look out and see people picking them up.”The -year-old started producing the toy packs at the start of April with help from his son Kenzy, , and his nine-year-old daughter, Skye.The trio decided to make the goodie bags in order to give back to their community.Nicky said: “This is me just wanting to do something nice and involve my kids too.“My daughter is well into her art so she asked me to include some of the colouring-in stuff.“The kids think it’s great.“They keep going out and looking at the kids from the window – I actually had to tell them to stop and let people have their privacy.”The team have also left out a notebook for people to leave them messages and feedback.The proud dad said: “We have had a decent handful of comments, along with some donations.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: north east charity to launch equipment library for children with additional support needs
story: A north-east charity helping children with additional support needs is appealing for donations to get its newest scheme up and running.Rainbow Rogues in Ellon is in the process of launching an Additional Support Needs Equipment Library, which will allow families of preschool children with additional  needs or disabilities to sample specialist equipment and sensory toys with their child before purchasing.The aim of the library is to reduce the amount of money that parents unnecessarily spend on items that are not suitable for their child#s development. However, the group require donations to begin operating the service.Rainbow Rogues manager, Jude Scofield, said: “When I joined the group as manager a year ago, this was one of the ideas I initially had.“I wanted to provide an additional service which was not just for the benefit of the families that attend Rainbow Rogues, but for families from across the north-east who have a child with additional support needs.”The scheme has been worked on over the last six of months. However, the Covid- pandemic has delayed it from launching.Jude added: “We are relying on grants and donations. But at this time, a lot of grant giving schemes have been put on hold so they can focus their attention and money on dealing with the effects of the pandemic.“This is why we have gone public to try to get support from the local community in the hope that they will make donations to help us.”The items will be available for hire for as little as £ a week and include ear defenders, pushchairs, supportive bedding and seating, and much more.Parents can then make an informed choice about whether the expense for the product is justied.Jude said: “We currently have a Safe Space Voyager which is a single mattress sized travel bed that is fully secure, and A Firefly GoTo Seat which provides a supportive seat so that a child with low muscle tone can be helped to sit upright.“As well as this, there are also three pushchairs, a bed tent which is placed over a single mattress to be used instead of a cot, and a weighted lap-pad.”The charity has also created an Amazon Wish List to allow members of the public, manufacturers and local businesses to donate products rather than just money alone.“We have received a large amount of items from our Amazon Wish List including ear defenders, wrist bands, PECS sets and seat belt safety devices,” Jude added.“We are confident that this scheme will be a success and hope the kindness of strangers will help us achieve our goal.“I hope it ensures that no family wastes money on unsuitable equipment for their children.”For more information, visit rainbowrogues.org.ukFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: remembering the man who almost created a very different his majestys theatre for aberdeen
story: His Majesty’s Theatre is an Aberdeen icon, standing proudly on Rosemount Viaduct, part of the trinity of “education, salvation and damnation” alongside the Central Library and St Mark’s Church.But the imposing building we all know and love today might have looked very dferent.Original plans by revered theatre architect Frank Matcham – who died on May ,  years ago – were for a very dferent design when he first submitted them in .“It was a strange thing, with lots of pillars and twin towers at either end, but that was rejected by the planners and he was sent back to the drawing board,” said Alan Rennie, archivist for Aberdeen Performing Art.“So His Majesty’s could have looked very dferent, totally symmetrical and a bit odd. I don’t think it would have sat on the site very well.”The plans the architect submitted next became the beautul, soaring, granite-built His Majesty’s with its signature copper-dome.It is now one of Britain’s treasured “Matcham theatres” standing alongside the London Palladium, the Hackney Empire, and the Glasgow King’s. And let’s not forget the Granite City’s own Tivoli Theatre, which, while not built by Matcham, was re-modelled by the London-based architect.Matcham was the “go-to” architect for theatres at the turn of the century, which was why he was commissioned to build HMT by Robert Arthur, a theatre impresario who decided Aberdeen needed a bigger and better venue as the s dawned.It#s on a clf thatHowever, Matcham had his work cut out for him in building His Majesty’s from scratch on a site that at first glance is the last place you would put a theatre.“It’s on a clf that just goes all the way down from the viaduct,” said Alan.“His main problem was how was he going to fit a theatre into that dficult site.“It was a fair undertaking as to how he could actually do it,” said Alan, adding part of the solution was to have the theatre stage two floors below ground level, unique at the time.“But he was renowned for fitting theatres into all sorts or shapes and sizes.”When HMT opened in , at a cost of £, but delayed by four years due to a shortage of Kemnay granite, it was a stunning addition to the cityscape – and one proudly built by local craftsmen.“That is one thing to stress, that most of the work was done by local artisans from the actual building of it to the interiors including the plasterwork,” said Alan.It was the distance from Matcham’s London-based operation which compelled him to use the Granite City’s home-grown talent.The interior of His Majesty’s was equally attractive as the exterior, a symphony of Italian marble, polished mahogany, and elegant plaster decorations, with rich velvet drapes and seating against an off-white colour scheme.A frieze of the “the Goddesses Of Drama” ran across the top of the proscenium arch and was created by William Buchan of Belmont Street. He also sculpted the statues of Tragedy and Comedy sitting above the boxes.Alan said the style could be described as “as sedate Georgian with a touch of Baroque” from a designer, whose other theatre designs have included themes like giving an auditorium a circus feel, with elephants above the boxes, or a Roman look with chariots around the walls.“His Majesty’s has a lovely, restrained auditorium from Matcham. There’s just enough glamour and splendour to make it look good,” said Alan.It has a“One thing Matcham was good at was sightlines in auditoriums.#He used fairly new cantilever technology.#Theatres of that period usually had pillars all over the place, but he managed to introduce a patented system to hold up the dress circle, upper circle and balcony above which gave excellent sightlines.#No matter where you are in the theatre, you can see to the back of the stage.#The challenges of the site made for some unique feature at His Majesty’s – not least that it has a river running underneath it.“The Denburn was one of the problems he had to overcome and still runs underneath the corner at the back of the theatre,” said Alan, adding this quirk had been forgotten for many years until work on a new fly tower in the s uncovered a culvert carrying the burn.“So they had to put a new bridge in over the Denburn.#You can sometimes hear it on a quiet day after a lot of rain in the corner of the theatre I inhabit.”When it opened in , HMT had a unique feature. The dress circle, where the wealthy and beautul people of Aberdeen sat, was at street level. This meant the upper crust of the day could sweep out of their carriages at the front door and straight into their plush seats without having to climb any stairs.Alan said: “There are pictures knocking around of people in their carriages being met at the front door by the doorman and pageboys, then escorted in. The carriages then used to go and park up roughly where Victoria Park is now and the little page boys would be sent up there to get them all back in time to pick up the posh clientele.”The hoi polloi, though, were not quite so well-catered for. The cheap seats in the balcony had their own entrance and things were a little less refined for the working folk.“Back in Matcham’s day the classes were certainly kept very much apart, so he managed to introduce separate entrances at the front,# said Alan.#The posh folk went through the main door and the balcony entrance was further apart.#You tramped all the way up a concrete stairway to get to the very top.You were literally“Up in the balcony there were benches, you found yourself a space with your family and you were literally pushed up with a brush-like contraption to fit more people into the building. You basically sat there and lent on the knees of the person behind you… and then smoked. It must have been fairly horrendous up there.”The separation of the rough and smooth in Aberdeen society continued in the stalls where a wooden fence kept the workers in their place at the rear of the auditorium away from all the finery of the “orchestra stalls”.Another quirky aspect of His Majesty’s is that the steep drop from the viaduct meant that the stage is above street level.Matcham got round this by installing a lt to hoist scenery and props to the backstage area for the get-in of productions.Alan said: “Scenery arriving at the Joint Station would be taken up to the theatre on handcarts and then loaded onto the lt and hand-winched up to the stage level.#It would have taken some time in those days to get things up and down. I think that’s unique in British theatre.”Strange noises andIt was a highly dangerous contraption, which led to His Majesty’s having its own ghost, Jake.In  a circus was performing at the theatre and horses were being hoisted up to the stage door, but was overloaded.John “Jake” Murray leaned over to apply the brake but was decapitated by the spinning winch-handle. Soon after strange noises and odd sightings troubled the theatre – and still do, according to some.Alan’s personal favourite aspect of Matcham’s theatre is the view from the stage.He said: “You just think ‘this is really lovely and quite magnicent’.#When we have companies come into the theatre stand on the stage the first thing they usually say is ‘isn’t this gorgeous, we weren’t expecting anything as lovely and pristine as this’.We are“Despite all the changes over the years, the original concept by Frank Matcham has remained intact. It stands as an architectural gem and an important contributor to Aberdeen’s cultural heritage.“We are lucky to have it.”Frank Matcham’s other gt to Aberdeen was the Tivoli.The Guild Street theatre was actually the city’s original Her Majesty’s, before the Rosemount Viaduct building was commissioned to create a bigger venue.Mark Fox, chairman of The Frank Matcham Society, explained the architect worked his magic on the Tivoli twice, breathing new le into a building which was built in  by architect CJ Phipps.“The Tivoli was a major reconstruction on Matcham’s part and he visited twice – having in between those two reconstructions built His Majesty’s entirely,# said Mark.#Aberdeen was obviously an important place to him.“In , Matcham went in and did some alterations to theauditorium. It was a major rebuild in , increasing the capacity and changing exits and allowing boxes, to create a greater intimacy in the auditorium. It operated as a music hall then.”Mark believes Aberdeen is very fortunate to have not one, but two Matchams to its credit.“They are both prime examples of his master#s art. The Frank Matcham Society had a trip up in  so I have seen them both and they are such pretty interiors. There’s the Romanesque finish of His Majesty’s compared to that very delicate cake icing, Baroque, Tivoli auditorium.”Today Matcham theatres around the country are treasured – each one distinctive in architectural style and tone # although they weren’t built to last.“When the buildings went up, because they were very commercial ventures, they were seen as ephemeral buildings,” said Mark.“If a building didn’t work, the developer would think nothing of knocking it down and doing something . If it did work, the chances are they would knock it down to build something bigger so they could make even more money.”London-based Matcham was a prolic architect, creating some  theatres and re-modelling a further . Today only  survive, along with HMT and the Tivoli.Mark said: “We have to put our hands out and say very much thank you to bingo.#Becausebingo hadn’t take over the Tivoli, it probably wouldn’t have survived. Then it had all those years, from  when it still stood empty,” he said praising today’s work to re-open it and build it up.Those Matchams which still stand are loved for a reason, said Mark.“He knew what he was doing. He was being appointed by commercial operators to create these spaces to make money, but he understood they would only workthey pleased everybody involved.“He had an understanding of what the performer needed, so the acoustics in all the venues are very good, so performers love them. And the designs always ended up with a level of intimacy between the stage and the audience that no other architect has managed. He made sure every seat in the house had a good view of the stage.“His buildings have a magic about them. You don’t need to be a theatre lover to go into one of Matcham’s buildings and appreciate what he created. If you ask anyone what their image of a theatre is, eventhey have never been in one, they will describe a Matcham theatre.”His Majesty’s is one of the stars in Frank Matcham’s legacy for British theatre.And over its long history, HMT has attracted countless stars of stage and screen – including those who can justiable be called Hollywood legends.Vivien Leigh, of Gone With The Wind fame, starred in a production of Bernard Shaw’s The Doctor’s Dilemma in , while Tyrone Power starred in the same writer’s the Devil’s Disciple in , billed in the Evening Express advert as “a personal visit of the famous American star”.One of the biggest Hollywood hitters was Charlton Heston, who arrived at His Majesty’s in  to star in A Man For All Seasons.Sean Connery also graced the stage – in the chorus of the musical South Pacic in both  an  before he picked up his licence to kill as .Other well-known faces to have peformed at the theatre over the years include, Alec Guinness, Noel Coward, Eric Sykes, Sade, Lulu, Rowan Atkinson, Andy Stewart and Billy Connolly, to name but a handful.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
