title: cardiff south penarth mp stephen doughty calls international cooperation tackle coronavirus new labour frontbench role
story: The MP for Cardf South and Penarth will work alongside the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Lisa Nandy, as a joint Shadow Foreign Office and International Development Minister for the African continent.He was previously appointed as Shadow Minister for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs until he resigned from the position in .During his live daily Q and A session yesterday, Mr Doughty said: "I got a call from the Sir Kier Starmer yesterday letting me know hed like me to be a Shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Development."Ill be working in two dferent teams with Lisa Nandy and Preet Kaur Gill - both fantastic people and Im delighted to be working with them."And the full front bench team was announced today so it will be a delight to go back and be in a shadow ministerial role."Its something that I feel Ive got a lot to contribute on but also is going to be so crucial because were seeing the impacts that coronavirus is having in this country with a developed health system with relatively strong levels of support for people, though I appreciate at the moment its incredibly dficult for people but compared to some countries around the world who literally dont have any of the type of equipment or expertise or staffing that we do in our health service."Im really fearful of some of the impact that will have in some of the poorest countries around the world, so this is undoubtedly going to be a big issue over the next few months and Im going to be working very closely with Kiers team to make sure we get the right support from governments across the world working together because were not going to solve this crisis by putting up barriers."Sir Keir won the Labour leadership contest in the first round of voting at a ballot last week, where he competed against Lisa Nandy and Rebecca Long-Baily.Mr Doughty has previously expressed his support for Sir Keir and called his victory a ray of hope. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cafe offers delivery service help need
story: Staff at the Marie Curie Hospice in Penarth" Café offers delivery service to help those in needCharlotte Court , co-owner of Willmore#s , delivers food parcels ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtto Llandough lt spangtlt spangt" Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA LOCAL cafeacute has started a regular food delivery service to support frontline staff and their patients who are suffering from Covid- at Llandough Hospital.The co-owners of Willmorersquos  on Stanwell Road, Matthew Holland and Charlotte Court, have delivered over  meals to frontline facilities in Penarth since the beginning of the pandemic, including the Marie Curie Hospice on Bridgeman Road.Now the pair have plans to extend their operations.They have raised over pound for the charitable cause, which includes money collected in a fundraiser by the community support group, Helping Hands Penarth.ldquoWe closed the shop three weeks ago and used all the leftover stock to do the first delivery to the hospital, explained Matthew.ldquoWersquove all got to be doing something and we felt like we had to utilize the shop and give something back to the guys that are putting their lives at risk.ldquoPenarth is a really small town and yoursquove just got to try and support each other as much as possible.ldquoI think yoursquove got to step up and do as much as you can,you can. Wersquove got the capacity to do it.Matthew went on to describe the atmosphere at Llandough Hospital.ldquoWersquore both in Penarth and wersquove lived here all our lives. Its important to us that we support it as much as possible.ldquoIts uplting being able to do that. It was so emotional being able to see the nurses on the Covid ward.ldquoFor me and Charlotte it was very humbling because those guys are putting their lives at risk and theyrsquore asking for stuff for patients, not for themselves.ldquoWe were quite tearful because we didnrsquot want to leave them there ndash but theyrsquore doing it day in-day out without batting an eyelid. Amazing people.Alongside their charitable work, Matthew and Charlotte have adapted to the challenging economic climate by introducing a delivery service for their customers.The pair have been working without the support of their staff who they had to furlough after the government closed all non-essential shops.ldquoWersquove started doing take-out because we canrsquot afford to do nothing for three months. title: strategy announced lead wales lockdown
story: The framework will help to determine when the strict stay-at-home restrictions can begin to be relaxed in Wales and will help to find a way for people in Wales to live and work alongside coronavirus.A Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing is being developed through the office of the Chief Medical Officer, Dr Frank Atherton. This will highlight the importance of community testing and support the containment of emerging coronavirus infections as and when restrictions are eased.Launching the framework, the First Minister said: ldquoOur approach to date has been one of lockdown. We have taken unprecedented steps to protect everyone, but particularly those most at risk from serious illness.ldquoThis has helped the NHS prepare and cope with coronavirus and, even though we have sadly seen more than  people die, it has helped to save many more lives. But this strategy comes with its own costs to peoplersquos wider health and wellbeing and long-term costs to our economy.ldquoWe are keeping these regulations under constant review. We know coronavirus will be with us for a long time yet but we want to see whether there are things we can do while we continue to tackle the virus and while the search for better treatments and a vaccine continue.The framework ndash and the seven questions ndash will help determine when the time is right to relax some of the stay-at home regulations.The seven questions are:bull Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus bull Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection bull How can it be monitored and enforced bull Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences bull Does it have a positive economic benefit bull Does it have a positive impact on peoplersquos wellbeing bull Does it have a positive impact on equality The Chief Medical Officer for Walesrsquo office has developed the Wales-wide programme of surveillance, case identication, and contract tracing.It will have four main strands ndash improved surveillance of cases of coronavirus effective identication of cases and contact tracing learning from international experience and engaging with the public.Dr Atherton said: ldquoAction to ease the lockdown restrictions will need to be supported by a comprehensive public health response, which will need to developed quickly and at scale.ldquoAcross the UK, we have worked and put in place unprecedented measures to contain and delay the spread of coronavirus. We have also worked to reduce the overall impact of the virus by strengthening essential services, including healthcare.ldquoWe are now working towards a new recovery phase to lead us out of the pandemic but only when the conditions are right.The First Minister added: ldquoCoronavirus is not going to disappear ndash it is likely it will be with us for a long time. We will need to have some sort of restrictions in place for some time yet to continue to control the spread of the virus and reduce community transmission. This framework will help us determine what is right for Wales.ldquoThere is a long road ahead of us towards recovery to pre-pandemic levels, butwe continue to work together, I hope we will be able to make changes to the restrictions and see a gradualto something resembling normal le.The Welsh Government has worked closely with the rest of the UK throughout the pandemic and has shared the development of the framework with the Scottish, Northern Irish and the UK governments. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a commentOrder byOldest firstNewest firstHighest scoredLowest scoredLoading comments... title: double transplant boys parents welcome donor law change
story: But five-year-old Frankie Lordrsquos mother Sophie Mansuy said parents of child donors would still need to make the dficult decision to consent, as the law change will not affect under-s.Frankie, from Lemington, Newcastle, was born with a serious heart condition and needed surgery immediately after he was born. vw, px"Frankie Lord was taken away for surgery the minute he was born Months later he was diagnosed with heart failure and was eventually put on the urgent transplant list.A donor heart became available and Frankie was given the gt of le, but the anti-rejection heart medication he needed damaged his kidneys and he needed dialysis three times a week.Frankie underwent a kidney swap after his father Chris was found to be a match. vw,vw,px, px"Frankiersquos health improved after his father Chris donated a kidney Ms Mansuy welcomed the new legislation, saying: ldquoTen years from now, I hope the shortage of organ donors will be a distant memory.ldquoI remember the day that I was told Frankie was in complete heart failure and needed a new heart. Lots has happened since then, but that memory is one Irsquoll never forget.ldquoThe chances of Frankie receiving a donor heart were slim. Not only because Frankie was small and underweight but because not many people, understandably, choose to donate their childrsquos organs once theyrsquove passed away. vw, px"Frankie was undergoing dialysis when his brother Freddie was a baby ldquoThe new laws that are coming in are great as people will start to talk about organ donation more, but when it comes down to parents donating their childrenrsquos organs it really is  times trickier.ldquoBefore I had Frankie, my mum always said that she wanted to donate her organs and it really used to scare me. Thinking about her not being here and someone  having a part of her.ldquoBut then reality hit me when my son needed a heart and I found myself waiting to seea family would make that really dficult decision.ldquoI never thought it would happen to me, but it did. vw, px"His mother Sophie Mansuy thanked The Sick Childrenrsquos Trust for supporting the family when he was in hospital The family has been helped by The Sick Childrenrsquos Trust, a charity that supports relatives of young transplant patients by giving them a place to stay close to the childrenrsquos ward.Chief executive Jane Featherstone said: ldquoEvery day at The Sick Childrenrsquos Trust we meet families like Frankiersquos who are facing the agonising wait for the news that an organ has become available for their child.ldquoUntil more awareness is raised around organ donation for children The Sick Childrenrsquos Trust promises to be there for these families, giving them a comfortable place to stay just minutes away from their childrsquos hospital bedside..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Double transplant boy us parents welcome donor law change article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: author neil gaiman apologies lockdown journey new zealand skye
story: Neil Gaiman has apologised after ing to Scotland from New Zealand during the Covid- pandemic.The -year-old author was criticised during First Minister Nicola Sturgeonrsquos daily coronavirus briefing on Monday after it was revealed he had gone back to Skye.The American Gods writer said in a blog post that he travelled more than , miles from where he was living with his partner Amanda Palmer after they ldquoagreed they needed some space.On Tuesday, Gaiman apologised for his actions, saying he had ldquodone something stupid.He wrote: ldquoLike so many other people, my home le and work had been turned upside down by the Covid- lockdowns.ldquoI was panicked, more than a little overwhelmed and stuck in New Zealand.ldquoWhen I landed, the whole of the UK was under lockdown rules.ldquoI drove directly to my home in the UK, which is on Skye. I came straight here and Irsquove been in isolation here ever since.Police officers spoke to him at his home and told himhe was safe in New Zealand he should have remained there.He added: ldquoSince I got here, Skye has had its own tragic Covid outbreak ndash  deaths in a local care home.ldquoItrsquos not set up to handle things like this and all the local resources are needed to look after the local community.ldquoI made a mistake. Donrsquot do what I did. title: cost gosford forest cones revealed

Gosford has been open and it is open to local people but becausethe car parkwas not open we were encouraging people to come and park on the hard shoulder.“It will cost £, to put traffic cones along that hard shoulder.”In response, the Council’s Strategic Director of People, Mark Parkinson said: “In respect of cones we will liaisewith the Police. I would totally agree the use of cones on this hard shoulderis fundamental and has made a dference previously.”Alderman Jim Speers said it “is only a matter of time before tragedy happens on that road” and called for a “permanent solution” to be found for this issue.“I must say, as members will be aware, I have raised this point on many occasions,” said the Ulster Unionist Party’s Cusher Councillor.“I have seen the cars parked on the main road but yesterdaythere were  to  cars parked down at the chapel crossroads as well.“It is only a matter of time before some tragedy happens on that road.“I have seen kids getting out of cars and kids running around and I have seen it on many occasions.    to cater for wrap advertlastScrollTop  stStatement issued by the four UK Chief Medical Officers Reporter: Ciara MaguireEmail: ciara.maguire@strabaneweeklyMonday  May  :A joint statement has just been issued from the four UK Chief Medical Officers on an update to coronavirus symptoms. “From today, all iniduals should self-isolatethey develop a new continuous cough or fever or anosmia. “Anosmia is the loss or a change in your normal sense of smell. It can also affect your sense of taste as the two are closely linked. “We have been closely monitoring the emerging data and evidence on COVID- and after thorough consideration, we are now confident enough to recommend this new measure. “The inidual’s household should also self-isolate for  days as per the current guidelines and the inidual should stay at home for seven days, or longerthey still have symptoms other than cough or loss of sense of smell or taste, they said. The statement is signed by Chief Medical Officer for Wales, Dr Frank Atherton, Chief Medical Officer for Northern Ireland, Dr Michael McBride, Chief Medical Officer for Scotland, Dr Gregor Smith and Chief Medical Officer for England, Professor Chris Whitty. Changes for the symptomatic inidual and their household: Iniduals will need to self-isolate immediatelythey develop a new continuous cough OR fever OR as of today, a loss or changed sense of normal smell or taste . All members of their household must also self-isolate according to current guidelines, unless the symptomatic inidual receives a negative test result.  addthis, Leave your commentTyrone Constitution-
